articles.headline: Struggling Cruise Cuts About 25 Percent of Its Workers
articles.snippet: The embattled self-driving car subsidiary of General Motors faces an uncertain future after California regulators shut down its robot taxi service in the state.
articles.abstract: The embattled self-driving car subsidiary of General Motors faces an uncertain future after California regulators shut down its robot taxi service in the state.
articles.lead_paragraph: Cruise, the embattled self-driving car subsidiary of General Motors, said on Thursday that it would eliminate about 900 jobs, roughly a quarter of its work force, as the company looked to rein in costs after an October incident led California regulators to shut down its robot taxi operations.

articles.headline: Washington Urges Israel to Scale Down Its War in Gaza
articles.snippet: The call for a more targeted phase in the war appeared to be the most definitive effort yet by the United States to restrain Israel in its retaliation against Hamas for the attacks it led on Oct. 7.
articles.abstract: The call for a more targeted phase in the war appeared to be the most definitive effort yet by the United States to restrain Israel in its retaliation against Hamas for the attacks it led on Oct. 7.
articles.lead_paragraph: Biden administration officials want Israel to end its large-scale ground and air campaign in the Gaza Strip within weeks and to transition to a more targeted phase in its war against Hamas, American officials said Thursday.
articles.byline: By Adam Entous, Aaron Boxerman and Thomas Fuller

articles.headline: TikTok Quietly Changes User Terms Amid Growing Legal Scrutiny
articles.snippet: Some lawyers say the changes could make it more difficult to bring legal action against the company.
articles.abstract: Some lawyers say the changes could make it more difficult to bring legal action against the company.
articles.lead_paragraph: Parents, schools and even attorneys general have increasingly been raising concerns about how TikTok may be hooking children to the app and serving them inappropriate content. But some lawyers say bringing legal action against the company could be more difficult after TikTok quietly changed its U.S. terms of service this summer.

articles.headline: Mistrust Looms Over PGA Tour as Deadline for Saudi Deal Nears
articles.snippet: Rancor within the tour’s board could shape decisions about the final agreement and influence the sport for decades to come.
articles.abstract: Rancor within the tour’s board could shape decisions about the final agreement and influence the sport for decades to come.
articles.lead_paragraph: The PGA Tour is less than three weeks from a deadline to finalize a deal with Saudi Arabia’s sovereign wealth fund that it promised would transform professional golf into a global powerhouse and quiet years of acrimony.
articles.byline: By Lauren Hirsch and Alan Blinder

articles.headline: ‘People Snatchers’: Ukraine’s Recruiters Use Harsh Tactics to Fill Ranks
articles.snippet: Ukrainian men are reporting incidents of wrongful draft notices, unprofessional medical commissions and coercive mobilization tactics.
articles.abstract: Ukrainian men are reporting incidents of wrongful draft notices, unprofessional medical commissions and coercive mobilization tactics.
articles.lead_paragraph: With Ukraine’s military facing mounting deaths and a stalemate on the battlefield, army recruiters have become increasingly aggressive in their efforts to replenish the ranks, in some cases pulling men off the streets and whisking them to recruiting centers using intimidation and even physical force.

articles.headline: Behind the Scenes at the Dismantling of Roe v. Wade
articles.snippet: This is the inside story of how the Supreme Court overturned the constitutional right to abortion — shooting down compromise and testing the boundaries of how the law is decided.
articles.abstract: This is the inside story of how the Supreme Court overturned the constitutional right to abortion — shooting down compromise and testing the boundaries of how the law is decided.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Feb. 10 last year, Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. showed his eight colleagues how he intended to uproot the constitutional right to abortion.
articles.byline: By Jodi Kantor and Adam Liptak

articles.headline: Private Gun Ownership in Israel Spikes After Hamas Attacks
articles.snippet: In a country already bristling with armed soldiers and reservists, a new sense of insecurity is pushing civilians to seek more personal weapons.
articles.abstract: In a country already bristling with armed soldiers and reservists, a new sense of insecurity is pushing civilians to seek more personal weapons.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two weeks ago, Zvika Arran reluctantly drew a gun at an Israeli state-run shooting class for those seeking firearms licenses, part of a massive spike in applications since the Hamas-led attacks on Oct. 7.
articles.byline: By Aaron Boxerman and Talya Minsberg

articles.headline: New Mexico Spaceport Leaves Economic Dreams Grounded
articles.snippet: Long a priority of local officials, the desert launchpad is sending tourists into space, but taxpayers and merchants are waiting for the payoff.
articles.abstract: Long a priority of local officials, the desert launchpad is sending tourists into space, but taxpayers and merchants are waiting for the payoff.
articles.lead_paragraph: From his tiny gem store in southern New Mexico, Robert Hanseck spends his days untangling chakra beads and answering questions about the healing properties of amethyst crystals. After four decades behind the register, he has met thousands of wellness-minded tourists eager to explore the hot springs that span the region.
articles.byline: By Kurtis Lee and Adria Malcolm

articles.headline: In Search of Cash, Studios Send Old Shows Back to Netflix
articles.snippet: When building their own streaming companies, many entertainment studios ended lucrative licensing deals with Netflix. But they missed the money too much.
articles.abstract: When building their own streaming companies, many entertainment studios ended lucrative licensing deals with Netflix. But they missed the money too much.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, entertainment company executives happily licensed classic movies and television shows to Netflix. Both sides enjoyed the spoils: Netflix received popular content like “Friends” and Disney’s “Moana,” which satisfied its ever-growing subscriber base, and it sent bags of cash back to the companies.
articles.byline: By John Koblin and Nicole Sperling

articles.headline: Zelensky Returns to Ukraine With Little Aid and a Raft of Needs
articles.snippet: The European Union’s willingness to open accession talks will lift morale, but the more immediate prospects for financial support from allies is sobering.
articles.abstract: The European Union’s willingness to open accession talks will lift morale, but the more immediate prospects for financial support from allies is sobering.
articles.lead_paragraph: With his soldiers fighting in snowy trenches and his cities under attack from Russian missiles, President Volodymyr Zelensky returned to Ukraine on Friday from a flurry of diplomatic meetings without major aid packages from the United States and Europe.
articles.byline: By Constant Méheut and Andrew E. Kramer
